candidates.title: Make net not include tokio-rustls.
candidates.body: This PR removes tokio-rustls as a dependency of the net feature so you only get TLS if you ask for it.

candidates.title: Update dependencies.
candidates.body:
This PR updates all dependencies to their latest major version. This requires some changes to the examples using tokio-rustls.

This PR also updates the minimum supported Rust version to 1.70.

This is a breaking change.

candidates.title: Add a queryable zone tree
candidates.body:
This PR adds `zonefile/parsed.rs`, `zonetree/` and related `examples/`, which together enable, and show a library user how, to go from a zone file in presentation format to an in-memory tree of zones which can be queried to provide an answer, or walked (iterated over).

The tree also supports versioned write operations and a trait based zone implementation allowing for the in-memory tree for a zone to instead be some other (a)synchornous backing store (as demonstrated by the `mysql-zone.rs` example).

It also simplifies the return type of `Service::call()` slightly by moving part of the type signature to the `Transaction` type.

candidates.title: Add the net::server module.
candidates.body:
This PR adds a `net::server` module to `domain` that enables the creation of UDP and TCP DNS servers using base transport server, middelware and service building blocks.

For examples of the code in use see:
- RustDoc tests.
- [`examples/server-transports.rs`](https://github.com/NLnetLabs/domain/blob/serve-poc/examples/server-transports.rs) - if you run this it prints various suggested `dig` commands you can run to see it in action.
- The Stelline test [`net-server.rs`](https://github.com/NLnetLabs/domain/blob/serve-poc/tests/net-server.rs).

Various things could be improved even without review feedback:
- [x] The `examples/serve.rs` is not neat and tidy at all and should maybe be split into multiple examples. - _Resolution: Tidied up a bit._
- [x] I'm not sure if the `net::server::prelude` is a good idea or not. - _Resolution: Removed._
- [ ] The code doesn't currently adhere completely to our desired coding guidelines.
- [x] The tests in `net::server::tests` haven't been looked at for a long time. - _Resolution: Reviewed, added some comments, did some minor cleanup._
- [x] The skeleton for dynamic reconfiguration support is present but not yet used. - _Resolution: It is now used._
- [x] The EDNS(0) timeout support might have the wrong idea about what EDNS(0) timeouts are, I haven't looked back at that for a long time. - _Resolution: This has been checked and updated._
- [x] The TODOs present in the code should be revisited. - _Resolution: Many TODOs have been resolved, some have been deliberately left behind as they require more thought._
- [x] No bechmarking / performance testing has been done yet. - _Resolution: Localhost testing with `dnsperf` and the 1M query set has been done yielding ~1.5M query/sec on the test machine for both UDP and TCP. This was done using the zone tree support in PR #286._
- [x] This PR doesn't have the discussed zonefile support yet. - _Resolution: See PR #286._
- [x] Review remaining calls to `unwrap()` - _Resolution: Unwraps removed, explained with SAFETY comment, or converted to expect() if truly fatal._

This PR also introduces tokio-tracing for async friendly context aware logging, e.g. one can capture the dns message id high up in a call tree and have it automatically included in a log message from deep in the call tree which I think is potentially very useful.

This PR is also probably incompatible with `--no-default-features` as that would disable the `std` feature yet this PR currently uses `std` functionality.

However, I think it's a good moment to take a look at it as-is.

candidates.title: Fix TXT record serialization.
candidates.body:
This PR fixes TXT record data serialization for human-readable formats. TXT record data is now serialized as a sequence of character strings. It also deserializes from such a sequence. If supported by the format, it alternatively deserializes from a string that is broken up into 255 octet chunks if necessary.

It uses a newly added helper type `base::charstr::DeserializeCharStrSeed` that deserializes character strings by appending them to an octets builder. Since this may be useful for other cases, it has been made public.

This is a breaking change.

This fixes #268.

candidates.title: Redesign `CharStr` formatting and serialization.
candidates.body:
This PR redesigns the conversion of `CharStr` from and to text formats.

It distinguishes between three text formats: quoted and unquoted representation format (i.e., what’s used in zonefiles) and a serialization format which is an unquoted format with only backslash and non-printable octets escaped. The latter will be used in serialization but also by default for `Display`. This makes it reversible with the `FromStr` implementation but avoids escaping white space. Methods for explicitly displaying in quoted and unquoted representation format are provided.

Serialization works mostly as before but uses the serialization format rather than the unquoted representation format in human-readable formats. It still uses the raw octets in binary formats.

The PR adds proper documentation for all of it to the type.

This is a breaking change.

candidates.title: Add OctetsFrom and Debug impls for AllOptData.
candidates.body:
This PR adds implementation for `OctetsFrom` and `Debug` to `AllOptData`. As a consequence, this also adds these to some of the option data types and changes `Debug` for some of them to be available for all octets sequences.

This is a breaking change via a necessary breaking change in `octseq`.

candidates.title: Remove interop and ci-test features and set interop tests to ignore.
candidates.body: This PR removes the interop and ci-test features which were used to gate tests that rely on additional software being installed on the test system. This was brittle as it required new features to be added to the ci-test feature or they would not be tested in the CI workflow. Instead, we now simply add the `#[ignore]` attribute to these tests and can use `--all-features` without issue.

candidates.title: Update `heapless` to 0.8.
candidates.body: Depends on https://github.com/NLnetLabs/octseq/pull/47.

candidates.title: Fix `no_std`.
candidates.body: Compiling on `no_std` is currently broken since both `octseq` and `time` have default `std` features enabled.

candidates.title: Compile in `no_std` context
candidates.body: Previously, the crates didn't compile in `no_std` context because some dependencies required std by default.

candidates.title: Replace `futures` dependency with `futures_util`
candidates.body:
The latter is sufficient, and the former pulls over a dozen additional unused dependencies.

Closes: https://github.com/NLnetLabs/domain/pull/245

candidates.title: Upgrade minimum Rust version to 1.67.
candidates.body: This PR upgrades the minimum Rust version to 1.67 due to some dependencies requiring that.

candidates.title: Move `flatten_into` for flattening domain names into a trait.

labels.name: breaking
labels.description: A PR that includes a breaking change.

candidates.body:
This PR moves the `flatten_into` method present on various types that either are or contain domain names into a `FlattenInto` trait.

Turns out that flattening is not only necessary for parsed names as I originally thought but also in chained names such as those produced by the current version of the zonefile parser.

The PR removes the method from all types that aren’t or don’t contain domain names and only had it to be able to make the big record data type enums.

With apologies to @xofyarg who originally proposed this as a trait and, turns out, was right.

candidates.title: Follow octseq change.
candidates.body: This PR follows a breaking change in _octseq_ that changes the names of the methods for integer parsing.

candidates.title: Drop random feature and use rand.
candidates.body:
This PR drops the separate `random` feature and uses `rand` instead.

This is a breaking change.

Fixes #194.

candidates.title: Refactor OPT options.
candidates.body:
This PR refactors the existing support for OPT options. It does the following things:

* Changes all option data types to ensure their wire format is at most 65,535 octets long. This requires changing the signatures of some creator functions. Their naming scheme and signatures are also changed to follow the pattern established with record data.
* Renamed `UnknownOptData::from_octets` to `new` and return a result.
* Completely redesigns DNS cookie options, adding support for standard server cookies introduced in RFC 9018.
* Change the type of `ExtendedError`’s text to `Str<Octs>` and change the return type of `set_text` to `()`.
* Changed the type `TcpKeepalive`’s content to a newtype `IdleTimeout` to make it easier to convert to and from durations.
* Changes Padding to just contain the padding octets and drop `PaddingMode`. Instead, the methods on OptBuilder` should be used to add padding.

This is a breaking change.

candidates.title: Fix new Clippy warnings and drop tokio-native-tls dependency.
Add basic parse/compose tests to options.
candidates.body: This PR adds a basic compose/parse test to most options. It skips those that are known to require some refactoring. Those will have their tests added later.

candidates.title: The Great octseq Conversion
candidates.body:
This PR swaps the traits and types defined in `base::octets` for their equivalent in the `octseq` trait. These are mostly the same except that they facilitate Generic Associated Types as stabilized in Rust 1.65. This results in subtly changed trait bounds, though mostly these should be invisible to the user.

One notable change is that `octseq` makes the error type of the `OctetsBuilder` generic and uses `Infallible` for those types where appending data will never fail (which, for most users, is all of them). It provides methods for either case and we are mirroring these in `domain`. While this means that converting you code to using the PR will require some work, that work should mostly be removing unwraps – which is nice.

We’re using the opportunity to clean up a few more things that have crept into the code over time. A list of which will be added here:

*  The range, slice, and split methods on the domain name types have changed. They have been merge into a single method taking ranges – except for those on `Dname` that require type changes. The split methods now take references and don’t change `self` anymore. This is somewhat required by the limitations imposed by the new `Octets` trait but feels better, anyway.

* The `Parse`, `Compose`, and `Scan` traits have been demoted to mere extension traits for foreign types (primarily the built-in integers, so that you can do things like `u16::parse`). All other types now simply have methods matching the patterns. Where generics are necessary, dedicated traits have been added. E.g., there now are `ParseRecordData` and `ComposeRecordData` traits that are implemented by all record data types.

* Composing of record data and options has been switched to a scheme where the size is predetermined whenever possible instead of composing the data and then updating the length after. Since this is not possible for record data that uses compressed names when compression is actually in use, the old scheme is still used in this particular case.

candidates.title: Switch to edition 2021.
candidates.body: Fixes #143.

chosen_pr.title: Make net not include tokio-rustls.
chosen_pr.body: This PR removes tokio-rustls as a dependency of the net feature so you only get TLS if you ask for it.

chosen_detail.body: This PR removes tokio-rustls as a dependency of the net feature so you only get TLS if you ask for it.
